titleStmt.title: Deletion of the activating NK cell receptor NKG2D accelerates rejection of cardiac allografts

analytic.title: Deletion of the activating NK cell receptor NKG2D accelerates rejection of cardiac allografts

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: It has already been shown that neutralization of the activating NK cell receptor NKG2D in combination with co-stimulation blockade prolongs graft survival of vascularized transplants.
In order to clarify the underlying cellular mechanisms, we transplanted complete MHC-disparate BALB/c-derived cardiac grafts into C57BL/6 wildtypes or mice deficient for NKG2D (Klrk1 −/− ).

Although median survival was 8 days for both recipient groups, we detected already at day 5 posttransplantation significantly greater intragraft frequencies of NKp46 + NK cells in Klrk1 −/− recipients than in wildtypes.
This was followed by a significantly greater infiltration of CD4 + , but a lesser infiltration of CD8 + T cell frequencies.

Contrary to published observations, co-stimulation blockade with CTLA4-Ig resulted in a significant acceleration of cardiac rejection by Klrk1 −/− recipients, and this result was confirmed by applying a neutralizing antibody against NKG2D to wildtypes.

In both experimental setups, grafts derived from Klrk1 −/− recipients were characterized by significantly higher levels of interferon-γ mRNA, and both CD4 + and CD8 + T cells displayed a greater capacity for degranulation and interferon-γ production.

In summary, our results clearly illustrate that NKG2D expression in the recipient is important for cardiac allograft survival, thus supporting the hypothesis that impairment of NK cells prevents the establishment of graft acceptance.
The influence of natural killer (NK) cells in solid organ transplantation (SOT) has been comprehensively illustrated,1 although their exact role is still a matter of controversial discussion.

Infiltration of NK cells in renal and cardiac allografts before evidence of T cell infiltration has already been observed shortly after transplantation, thus supporting the role of these cells as early innate effector cells in response to inflammatory stimuli.

However, whereas authors report that NK cells are important for tolerance induction either by killing graft-derived antigen-presenting cells (APCs) 2-4 or by downregulating the homeostatic proliferation of CD8 + memory T cells,5 other publications illustrate their involvement in allograft destruction and the development of chronic allograft vasculopathy.
6 Apart from their functional role as "killers," recent reports even suggest that NK cells also possess adaptive immunity properties.7,8

The NK cell-mediated initiation and regulation of an alloimmune response posttransplantation might rely on the differentiation and activation status of NK cells, their expression of activating as well as inhibitory receptors and their binding of corresponding ligands tipping the balance towards either tolerance or rejection.
In light of this, the definition of polymorphic receptor genotype expression and its association with allograft outcome have meanwhile been extensively investigated by us and others.9,10

On the other hand, the functional relevance of individual NK cell receptors in SOT has been studied exclusively for the activating cytotoxicity receptor NKG2D, which is also expressed by activated (human) or constitutively by (mouse) CD8 + T cells,11,12 subsets of NKT cells, and interferon (IFN)-γ-producing killer dendritic cells.

13 This homodimeric C-type, lectinlike receptor binds to stress-inducible ligands including H60 a, b, and c,14 retinoic acid early inducible gene (RAE-1α, -β, -γ, -δ, and -ε isoforms), 15 and the murine UL-16-binding protein-like transcript 1 (MULT-1).
16 It has been demonstrated that neutralization of NKG2D results in a significant prolongation of graft survival of vascularized BALB/c donor hearts transplanted in CD28 −/− C57BL/6 mice.17

In addition, recently published articles suggest that neutralizing NKG2D in combination with co-stimulation leads to prolonged survival of pancreatic allografts 18 and attenuates chronic allograft vasculopathy.19
However, no information is provided regarding the influence of NKG2D neutralization at the cellular and molecular level.

Therefore, we performed more profound experiments as previously reported using a NKG2D-deficient mouse in an acute transplantation setting and in a co-stimulation blockade setting of heterotopic heart transplantation.
Male C57BL/6 (H-2 b ) and BALB/c (H-2 d ) mice aged 10 to 12 weeks were purchased from Charles River (Sulzfeld, Germany).

NKG2D (Klrk1 −/− ) knockout mice on a C57BL/6 background were a kind gift from Dr. Bojan Polic.20 Animals were housed under standard conditions and received human care in compliance with the "Principles of Laboratory Animal Care" prepared by the National Academy of Sciences and published by the National Institutes of Health (NIH Publication No. 86 -23, revised 1985).
All experiments were approved by the Austrian Ministry of Education, Science and Culture (BMWF-66.011/0043-II/3b/2012).

For the acute rejection model, BALB/c donor hearts were heterotopically transplanted into either C57BL/6 or Klrk1 −/− recipient mice (n = 5-6/group) and sacrificed at day 5 (d5) or on the day of rejection (dRx).

For the co-stimulation model, C57BL/6 or Klrk1 −/− recipients of BALB/c allografts were treated with a single dose (10 mg/kg) of human CTLA4-Ig (Abatacept, Orencia; Bristol-Meyer Squibb, Munich, Germany) by ip injection on day 2 posttransplantation.

Control C57BL/6 mice were treated with 200-μg monoclonal anti-NKG2D antibody (clone: HMG2D) ip or a control Armenian hamster IgG isotype (BioXcell, West Lebanon, NH) on d0, d1, d3, d4, d5, and thereafter 3 times per week until rejection.
Allogeneic cervical heart transplantations were performed under injection anesthesia with ketamine/xylazine (AniMedica, Senden-Bösensell, Germany) as previously described.21
Cold and warm ischemia times for allografts were maintained at 10 minutes.
Rejection was defined as complete cessation of palpable ventricular contractions.
Mononuclear cells (MNCs) from spleen, lymph nodes, and allografts were isolated as previously described.22

For flow cytometry, 1 × 10 6 cells were pre-incubated with FcRblocking reagent (Miltenyi Biotech, Bergisch-Gladbach, Germany) for 15 minutes and afterwards stained with combinations of antibodies listed in Table 1.
Cells were analyzed on a FACSFortessa (BD Bioscience, Franklin Lakes, NJ) collecting a total of 100 000 events.
For analysis, only living cells were counted.
Moreover, doublet exclusion was achieved by plotting forward and sideward scatter areas, heights, and widths (FSC-and SSC-A/-H/-W).
Data were analyzed with FlowJo v 9.3 (Tree Star, Asland, OR).
The gating strategy is presented in Figure S1.

Functional analysis of NK and T cells was performed using isolated splenic MNC cultured in RPMI 1640 medium (Lonza, Verviers, Belgium) supplemented with 10% heat-inactivated fetal calf serum, 1% L-glutamine, 100 U/mL penicillin, and 100 μg/mL streptomycin (Gibco/ Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA) and 400 U/mL mIL-2 (eBioscience, San Diego, CA) at 37°C and 5% CO 2 for 20 hours.

Afterwards, MNCs were incubated in the presence or absence of 200 U/mL mIL-2, YAC-1 cells (with an effector:target ratio 2:1) or 50 ng phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate and 1 μg ionomycin calcium salt (Sigma-Aldrich, St Louis, MO) for 4 hours at 37°C and 5% CO 2 .
Degranulation capacity was assessed by CD107a expression assay.
After 1 hour, brefeldin A (1000x, eBioscience) was added for an additional 3 hours and cells were stained with antibodies listed in Table 1.

div.head: Quantitative reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction

p.s: Allografts were snap-frozen in liquid nitrogen and isolated splenocytes were frozen in lysis buffer at -20°C.

Real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction for gene expression analysis was performed as recently described 21 with the ABI PRISM 7500 Sequence Detection System (Life Technologies, Carlsbad, CA).
Primers were designed using Primer Express Software (Life Technologies) or directly purchased as Taqman ® gene expression assays (Life Technologies) (Tables 2 and 3).
Gene expression was normalized to the housekeeping gene hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase given by the formula 2 -ΔCt .

Tissues were fixed in 10% neutral buffered formalin and embedded in paraffin; 5-μm sections were stained with H&E and scored according to the International Society for Heart and Lung Transplantation (ISHLT) rejection score.23
Statistical analyses were performed using GraphPad Prism 5 (GraphPad Software, La Jolla, CA).
Kaplan-Meier plots were used to analyze graft survival, and a log-rank test was used to assess the statistical significance of differences between survival curves.
For normally distributed data, statistical significance between 2 groups was calculated using 2-tailed Student t tests and for more than 2 groups using 1-way ANOVA.
Adjustments for multiple comparisons were performed with the Tukey-Kramer comparison test.
Statistical significance was considered for the following P values: ns = P > .05,

div.head: Deletion of Klrk1 results in an early intragraft infiltration of NK cells

p.s: In a first set of experiments, we transplanted allogeneic BALB/c donor hearts into either naïve wildtype C57BL/6 mice or Klrk1 −/− mice.
No significant differences in allograft survival were observed between the 2 groups (median survival: 8 days for each group; P = n.s.) in this acute rejection setting (Figure 1A).
Histological analysis revealed that BALB/c grafts were characterized by a massive lymphocyte infiltration at d5 in both recipient groups (Figure 1B).

However, already at d5, heart grafts of Klrk1 −/− recipients were characterized by a significant infiltration of NKp46 + NK cells as compared with wildtype mice, and this observation was further confirmed for spleen (P < .001)
(Figure 1C).

Contrarily, at dRx we detected a significantly enhanced infiltration of CD4 + T cells into grafts of Klrk1 −/− recipients, whereas significantly lower frequencies of CD8 + T cells were observed (P < .
In addition, spleens and lymph nodes of Klrk1 −/− mice showed enhanced frequencies of major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class II + CD11c + dendritic cells as early as d5 (P < .01)
as well as dRx (P < .001
for spleen, Figure 1C).
Interestingly, Klrk1 −/− mice had significantly fewer numbers of regulatory T (T REG ) cells in lymph nodes at d5 (P < .05)
(Figure S2).

div.head: Klrk1 −/− -derived T cells illustrate greater degranulation capacity and IFNγ production

p.s: Whereas no differences for RAE1, MULT-1, and H60 mRNA in allografts between Klrk1-/recipients and wildtype mice were observed (data not shown), ligand expression of RAE1 g was induced between d5 and dRx on both splenic conventional dendritic cells (cDC) and plasmacytoid cells (pDCs).
Especially cDCs derived from Klrk1-/-lymph nodes displayed significantly weaker ligand expression than did wildtype mice (Figure 2A).

Both splenic CD4 + and CD8 + T cells showed significantly greater degranulation capacity and IFNγ production, whereas NK cells derived from Klrk1 −/− mice were impaired for degranulation but not for IFNγ production (Figure 2B).

Intragraft cytokine expression at d5 revealed significantly stronger mRNA expression of inflammation markers including IFNγ, IL-15, and CXCL10 (P < .05) in Klrk1 -/mice, whereas expression of the anti-inflammatory cytokine IL-10 was clearly reduced (P < .05)
(Figure 2C).
Splenocyte analysis revealed significant differences solely for Granzyme B mRNA levels.
No further changes were observed for IL-2, IL-15, CCL5, CXCL10, and IFNγ (Figure S3).

In summary, our data clearly illustrate that a deletion of Klrk1 in the recipient results in enhanced intragraft infiltration of NK cells and CD4 + T cells posttransplantation, weaker NKG2D ligand expression on cDCs and pDCs in lymph nodes, enhanced IFNγ production, and degranulation capacity of CD4 + and CD8 + T cells parallel with an induction of inflammatory cytokines.

div.head: Klrk1 deficiency of the recipient results in accelerated rejection of allogeneic grafts under costimulation blockade

p.s: It has been demonstrated that the neutralization of NKG2D in combination with costimulation blockade results in prolonged cardiac graft survival.17,

19 We therefore transplanted BALB/c-derived hearts into either C57BL/6 or Klrk1 -/mice receiving a single dose of abatacept at d2 posttransplantation.22 Surprisingly, whereas co-stimulation blockade resulted in a median survival of 50 days in wildtype animals, Klrk1 -/mice treated with abatacept displayed significantly reduced graft survival (median survival: 27 days; P = .
We repeated these experiments applying a neutralizing antibody against NKG2D.

Again, we were able to illustrate that NKG2D-neutralized wildtype mice under costimulation blockade displayed significantly reduced graft survival as compared with mice treated with an isotype control (median survival: 22.5 days versus 47.5 days; P = .0074),
which is comparable with the graft survival of Klrk1 -/mice (Figure 3A).
At d20, the time when hearts engrafted into Klrk1 -/mice start to be rejected, allografts were characterized by a higher although not significant ISHLT rejection score (Figure 3B).
Thus, our survival data clearly illustrate that under co-stimulation blockade NKG2D expression of the recipient is important for allograft survival.

div.head: NK cell infiltration in cardiac grafts is impaired under co-stimulation blockade

p.s: Contrary to the acute rejection setting (Figure 1C), frequencies of graft-infiltrating NKp46 + NK cells at d5 were significantly reduced in Klrk1 -/mice under co-stimulation blockade, whereas splenic CD4 + T cells were decreased and CD8 + T cells increased.
At d20 no differences between wildtype in Klrk1 -/mice were observed anymore with the exception of elevated NK cell frequencies in lymph nodes (Figure 4).
In addition, these mice further demonstrated significantly elevated frequencies of splenic Treg (Figure S4).

div.head: Maintained degranulation capacity and IFNγ production of Klrk1 -/-T cells under costimulation blockade

p.s: We monitored RAE1 g expression on APCs and detected a significantly induced expression on cDCs and pDCs derived from Klrk1 -/spleens and lymph nodes already at d5. Induction on splenic cDCs was also observed at d20 (Figure 5A).
As in the acute model, both CD4 + and CD8 + T cells derived from Klrk1 -/mice still displayed enhanced degranulation capacity at d5 as compared with wildtype animals.
Contrarily, no differences were observed for NK cells under co-stimulation blockade at d5 (Figure 5B).
However, all investigated cell subtypes derived from knockout animals showed significantly elevated IFNγ expression at d5, which is inversed at d20.

Cardiac allografts derived from Klrk1 -/mice displayed significantly elevated mRNA levels of IFNγ, Granzyme B, and tumor necrosis factor-α (Figure 5C), and splenic gene expression analysis revealed an induction of IFNγ, IL-2, and CXCL10 (Figure S5).
The impact of NK cells for solid allograft survival remains elusive.
As illustrated by accumulating data, NK cells, apart from their role as early effector cells during acute rejection, are also involved in antibody-mediated rejection in the long term.24,25

Recently, a model of augmentation of host-adaptive alloimmunity by passenger lymphocytes was proposed, illustrating that donor-derived CD4 + T cells can provoke a marked and longlasting augmentation of cellular and humoral alloimmunity resulting in early allograft rejection.4
This augmentation is prevented by rapid NK cell killing of donor lymphocytes, supporting the role of NK cells as key mediators of tolerance by killing APCs.2,3
Our present data support this hypothesis, as we could not confirm published observations that a neutralization of NKG2D results in improved allograft survival.17,19

Consequently, 2 questions arise: first, why do these data contrast sharply with already published data, and, second, why is the deletion of NKG2D, an activating NK cell receptor, important for allograft survival although its functional importance for reactivity has been considerably illustrated in tumor models.
For instance, mice deficient for NKG2D or treated with an NKG2D-neutralizing antibody are more susceptible to primary tumorigenesis.
26 Direct comparison of our results with previous reports appears difficult, as we transplanted donor hearts cervically 21,22 and not heterotopically.17,19

Whereas others applied multiple dosages of CTLA4-Ig resulting in survival times of 30 or 60 days for cardiac grafts,17,19 we administered only 1 single application of CTLA-4 Ig at d2 posttransplantation, which led to a mean survival of 50 days.22
In our hands, multiple dosages of CTLA-4 Ig alone during the first week posttransplantation resulted in an overall allograft survival of >100 days (data not shown).
A significant decrease in CD8 + , CD4 + T cells and macrophages was observed under co-stimulation blockade and NKG2D neutralization at day 60.19
However, we did not detect differences in the same experimental set-up already at day 20 posttransplantation (Figure 4).

Moreover, the same authors conclude that expansion of T REG is one of the main mechanisms contributing to prolonged graft survival following NKG2D blockade, whereas we observed induced T REG frequencies in Klrk1 -/recipients, thus illustrating accelerated graft rejection (Figure S4).
Based on the strong alloreactivity in the acute model, we did not detect differences in graft survival (Figure 1A).
Although Klrk1 -/--derived NK cells at d5 are impaired in their degranulation capacity, they retain their IFNγ production.
On the other hand, CD4 + and CD8 + T cells derived from Klrk1 -/mice showed significantly greater degranulation capacity and IFNγ production than did their wildtype counterparts (Figure 2B).

This is surprising because NKG2D is thought to mediate co-stimulatory signals in NKG2D + T cells similar to CD28 by augmenting cytotoxic and proliferative responses of T cells, whereas NKG2D signaling directly induces NK cell-mediated cytolysis.

27 The significantly stronger IFNγ production and CD107 expression of Klrk1 -/--derived CD4 + and CD8 + T cells is still maintained under co-stimulation blockade (Figure 5B), suggesting that the lack of NKG2D does not impair the effector function of these cells.
In line with our findings, recent in vitro data illustrated that neutralization of NKG2D even promotes the differentiation of Th1 cells.
28 This supports our observations that NKG2D deficiency of NK cells might be compensated by the activation of CD4 + and CD8 + T cells, which is sufficient to mediate rejection.

Recent research highlights the fact that NK cells are also regulatory cells engaged in reciprocal interaction with dendritic cells, macrophages, T cells, and endothelial cells,2-6 thus limiting or exacerbating immune response.

For instance, NK cells are important for tolerance induction in recipients given donor splenocyte transfusion and anti-CD40L mAb as NK cells may regulate monocyte activation and infiltration into allografts by a mechanism partially dependent on NKG2D receptor-ligand interactions between both cell types.
29 We observed significantly greater frequencies of splenic NKG2D ligand-expressing DCs in the acute setting, although these cells were reduced in lymph nodes (Figure 2A).
Contrarily, in the co-stimulation model, frequencies of DCs and pDCs expressing RAE-1 g were significantly greater in both spleen and lymph nodes of Klrk1 -/recipients (Figure 5A).
The potential bidirectional cross-talk between NK cells and DCs plays a relevant role as both cells form a stimulatory synapse, which allows the secretion of IL-12 and IL-15 by DCs.
These cytokines upregulate the cytolytic function of NK cells and their release of IFNγ and TNFα.30
Intragraft mRNA expression of IFNγ is the hallmark of both experimental setups as well as the enhanced IFNγ production by Klrk1 -/--derived T cells.

We can only speculate that NKG2D deficiency leads to a functional impairment of NK cells but is compensated by activated T cells and finally leads to accelerated rejection under co-stimulation blockade.

Although further studies are necessary, our data clearly emphasize that in models where NK cells are impaired or depleted, transplant tolerance of MHC-mismatched allografts would be difficult to achieve.2-6
This result overturns the general belief that NK cells should be regarded solely as "killers" and shows that they appear to have an important regulatory role.
Refer to Web version on PubMed Central for supplementary material.

Figure 1.
Deletion of NKG2D does not accelerate rejection in an acute transplantation model, but results in induced graft infiltration of NK cells and CD4 + T cells.
(A) Allogeneic BALB/c hearts were heterotopically transplanted into C57BL/6 or Klrk1 -/mice.
Hearts were acutely rejected at 8 days (median) in both groups, n = 6/group.
(B) Exemplary pictures of graft histology illustrating that grafts harvested from either C57BL/6 or Klrk1 -/recipients were characterized by massive lymphocyte cell infiltration at dRx.
Scale bar = 100 μm.
(C) Analysis of lymphocyte subsets derived from allografts, spleen, and lymph nodes at d5 and
Figure 2.Phenotypic analysis of NKG2D ligand expression and functional analysis of effector functions in wildtype versus Klrk1 -/mice in the acute rejection setting.
(A) RAE-1 g expression on cDCs and pDCs derived from spleen and lymph nodes.
(B) Degranulation capacity and IFNγ production of T cells (CD4 + and CD8 + ) and NK cells after restimulation with IL-2 (T cells) or IL-2 + YAC-1 (NK cells).

For the exemplary FACS dot plot, CD3 + CD4 + and CD3 + CD8 + cells were pre-gated and displayed as forward scatter (FCS) versus CD107a and NK cells were pre-gated on NKp46 + CD3cells and displayed as NKp46
Figure 3. Deletion of NKG2D accelerates rejection under co-stimulation blockade.
(A) Allogeneic BALB/c hearts were heterotopically transplanted into C57BL/6 or Klrk1 -/mice receiving a single dose of abatacept (10 mg/kg) at day 2 (d2) posttransplantation.

Additionally, C57BL/6 mice were treated with a neutralizing antibody against NKG2D (200 μg at days 0, 1, 3, 4, 5, and thereafter 3 times per week until rejection) or isotype control antibody, n = 5-10/group.

(B) Histological evaluation of BALB/c allografts harvested at d20 from C57BL/6 or Klrk1 -/recipients illustrated a higher grade of rejection according to ISHLT rejection score (P = n.s.) and clearly stronger infiltration of total T cells as well as CD4 + and CD8 + T cells.
Exemplary histological figures of n = 4 animals are shown.
Data are presented as mean values for n = 4 animals/group.
